lines.text: And now *you* understand. Anything goes wrong, anything at all... your fault, my fault, nobody's fault... it won't matter - I'm gonna blow your head off. No matter what else happens, no matter who gets killed I'm gonna blow your head off.
[to his son]
You can call me Father, you can call me Jacob, you can call me Jake. You can call me a dirty son-of-a-bitch, but if you EVER call me Daddy again, I'll finish this fight.
Who are you?
Jacob McCandles.
I thought you were dead.
Not hardly.
Do this, do that! I'm gonna do whatever I want!

You do what he tells you, every time he tells you and we might come through this alive! Might even save the boy. Otherwise you're gonna get yourself killed. Don't matter to me, but you'll probably get him killed too, and that does.
I'll give you $500 now and another $500 when you get 'em to market.
That's highway robbery!
Well, maybe you think you're gonna get a better offer for 'em today?
I'll take it... with one proviso.
What's that?
I go with the sheep.

[Watching a sheepherder about to be hanged]
No sir; no sir I ain't. I ain't butted into somebody else's business since I was seventeen year old, at which time it almost got me killed.
[Dog growls deeply]
What's the matter with you?
[Looks down toward the hanging party; man kicks a young boy]
Aw, now... what'd he have to go and do that for?
They tell me you killed two good men in a fair fight tonight. That true?
No, three; countin' you.
Prove it.
Say, you don't look too good. The sight of blood bother you?
Only my own.
Throw a blanket over 'im (a horse).
I can ride without a blanket.
I'm not worrying about your butt! It's his back!
Well, if you can shoot that far, a quarter of a mile straight along the edge of my nose is a mountain buck. Shoot it.
I don't kill to make a point, Father.
Michael, there's two reason to kill - survival and meat. We need meat!
You're short on ears and long on mouth!
I am moved by your faith in someone you haven't seen since he was sixteen years old, Daddy!
Daddy?
Daddy.
Well, son; since you don't have any respect for your elders, it's time somebody taught you some respect for your betters!
[grabs James and throws him into a mud puddle]
Why, if you weren't my father...
Go ahead. I give you leave.
[James winds up to throw a punch, but before he swings, Jake hits him and knocks him back into the puddle]
They're very dangerous men. They've already killed ten people, many of them you know... Juan and his family...
Tina and the little boy?
And Moses Brown.
Old Mose... lousy cook.
What do you do when cockroaches get in the woodwork, Michael?
Smoke 'em out?
That's right.
Why not wait for them to make the first move?
Because waiting is good for them and bad for us. You get impatient, nervy, careless and maybe dead.
You come close, mister, but no cigar!

[Cocking his pistol]
No hard feelings, mister.

[Shoots him with a shotgun he has hidden in the shower stall]
The hell there ain't.
We rode down, thought you might be hirin'.
We was.
Was?
[looks around]
You know, this place sure speaks of a lot of money. You know what the problem with money is? Somebody's always trying to take it from you. Still, that's the only problem.
[Pulls gun and shoots Bert]
I thought you were dead.
Dead? The next person who says that I'm gonna shoot, so help me.
Boy mean anything to you?

Never laid eyes on em. But I'm being paid to bring em back alive or you dead. Each and everyone of you. Now I'd rather bring the boy back that's easier. But when it comes right down to it don't matter to me I'll earn my pay one way or the other. Now how about you? Are you the Big Chief or one of the little Indians?
Oh just a little Indian just a messenger boy.
This is going to be a very harsh and unpleasant business, and will take an equally harsh and unpleasant person to see to it.
Hank, where are your spurs?
You can't use 'em on these new velocopedes.
What about the boy? You gonna hang him too, or just beat him up some more?
Mister, you shouldn't butt into things that aren't your business, you really shouldn't.
That's more words than I've spoke since I knew ya'.
Martha, It been a long time, It good to see you again.
You've changed Jacob
Not you, Your as young and lovely as ever
You want to chance it Mother?
Buck?
No matter what happens I think they'll kill the boy sooner or later, Texas have the best rifleman in the world luck with 200 yards to hit them-...
It very daring yes, yes I chance it. What you think Jacob?
Suit yourself Martha
I was asking your opinion Jacob
No, You made up your mind and you made your decision alone, you live it alone
I was wrong you haven't change, have you Jacob McCandles
Not one bit.
Newspaper clippings. I killed a man for newspaper clippings.
I was wrong. You haven't changed, have you, Jacob McCandles?
Not one bit.
A ranch sure is a deserted looking place during a round-up.
Your fault, my fault nobody's fault.
Michael flies off mountain on his bike. Jacob rides down,impressive as JW did the gaff, to see if Michael is alive or dead
Take off your goggles.
Jacob punches Michael right in the face. Helps him up and punches him again.
Michael, sitting in the dirt and confused, says in a deep and serious voice..."Father, Father, the next time... Jacob interrupts WHAT?, "The next time I won't take off my goggles... CLASSIC
